qas.question: In what year was the term race first used in the U.S. Census?
How often was a new questionnaire sheet used in the 1890 census?
How were residents listed in the census in 1890?
Why were different East Asian races divided in 1890 Census?

context: For <a0_0>1890<a0_0/>, the Census Office changed the design of the population questionnaire. Residents were still listed <a2_0>individually<a2_0/>, but a new questionnaire sheet was used <a1_0>for each family<a1_0/>. Additionally, this was the first year that the census distinguished between different East Asian races, such as Japanese and Chinese, due to <a3_0>increased immigration<a3_0/>. This census also marked the beginning of the term "race" in the questionnaires. Enumerators were instructed to write "White," "Black," "Mulatto," "Quadroon," "Octoroon," "Chinese," "Japanese," or "Indian."
